titleStmt.title: Articles, of a treatie of truce. Made and concluded in the towne and citie of Antvverp, the 9. of April 1609. betweene the commissioners of the most excellent Princes, Arch-dukes Albert and Isabella Clara Eugenia, as well in the name of the Catholicke Kings Maiestie, as in their owne. Together with the commissioners and deputies of the renowmed Lords, the Estates Generall of the Vnited Prouinces of the Low-countryes and that through the mediation and with the aduice of the Lords Ambassadors of the most Christian Kings, and of Great Britaine. At the Haghe by Hillebrant Iacobz, printer ordinarie to the Lords of the States Generall of the Vnited Prouinces of the Low-countreyes.
Treaties, etc. United Provinces of the Netherlands. Staten Generaal, 1609 Apr. 9
titleStmt.author: Netherlands. Sovereign (1598-1621 : Albert and Isabella).

Made and concluded in the towne and citie of Antvverp, the 9. of April 1609. betweene the commissioners of the most excellent Princes, Arch-dukes Albert and Isabella Clara Eugenia, as well in the name of the Catholicke Kings Maiestie, as in their owne. Together with the commissioners and deputies of the renowmed Lords, the Estates Generall of the Vnited Prouinces of the Low-countryes and that through the mediation and with the aduice of the Lords Ambassadors of the most Christian Kings, and of Great Britaine. publicationStmt.publisher: Printed [by John Windet] for George Potter and Nicholas Brovvne [i.e. Bourne] and are to bee sold at his shoppe vnder the Royall Exchange,

notesStmt.note: The first leaf is blank except for signature-mark "A"; the last leaf is blank.
Running title reads: Articles of truce.
A variant (STC 18456) has "Brovvne" corrected to "Bourne" in imprint.
Reproduction of the originals in the Folger Shakespeare Library and the Henry E. Huntington Library and Art Gallery.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

2010-08 Megan MarionText and markup reviewed and edited

div.p: ARTICLES OF A TREATIE OF TRVCE.

Made and concluded in the Towne and C ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
tie of ANTVVERP, the 9. of April 1609. betwee ‚Ä¢ the Commi≈ø≈øioners of the mo≈øt Excellent Princes, Archdukes ALBERT and ISABELLA CLARA EVGENIA, as well in the name of the Catholicke KINGS Maie≈øtie, as in their owne.

Together with the Commi≈øsioners and Deputies the renowmed LORDS, the E≈øtates Generall of the Vnited Prouinces of the Low-countryes: and that through the mediation and with the aduice of the Lords Amba≈ø≈øadors of the mo≈øt Chri≈øtian Kings, and of Great BRITAINE.
AT THE HAGHE
By Hillebrant Iacobz, Printer ordinarie to the Lords the States Generall of the Vnited Prouinces of the Low-countreyes.
LONDON Printed for GEORGE POTTER and NICHOLAS BROVVN and are to bee ≈øold at his Shoppe vnder the Royall Exchange. 1609.

div.head: To the Reader.
div.p:
SO it is, that the mo≈øt excellent Princes, Archduke Albert and I≈øabella Clara Eugenia, &c. hauing vpon the foure & twentie of April, 1607. made a Truce and Ce≈ø≈øation of Armes, for eight moneths, with the mo≈øt renowmed Lords the generall E≈øtates of the vnited Prouinces of the Low-Countries in qualitie, and as holding them for free E≈øtates, Prouinces and Countries; ouer the which, they pretend no authority: The which Truce ought to be ratified with like declaration, by the Catholike Kings Maie≈øtie, for ≈øo much as might concerne him; and the ≈øaid ratifications and declarations deliuered to the ≈øaid Lords E≈øtates, three moneths after the ≈øaid Truce, as it is pa≈ø≈øed by Letters Patents of the eighteenth of September the ≈øaid yeare: And further, giueth a ≈øpeciall procuration to the ≈øaid Lords Archdukes, of the tenth of Ianuarie 1608. a≈øwell in his name as in their owne, to doe all that they ≈øhall iudge to bee fitte and conuenient, to attaine to a good Peace or Truce for many yeares. By vertue of which procuration, the ≈øaid Lordes Archdukes ≈øhould al≈øo by their letters of Commi≈øsion, of the 27. of the ≈øame moneth name and depute Commi≈øsioners, for to conferre and entreat in the ≈øaid names and qualities: and hereupon haue con≈øented and agreed, that the ≈øaid Truce ≈øhould bee prolonged and continued at
≈øundrie times: namely, the 20. of May, vnto the end of the ≈øaid yeare 1608.

But after they had a≈ø≈øembled them≈øelues diuers times with the deputies of the ≈øaid Lords E≈øtates, who had al≈øo procuration & Commi≈øsion from them, dated the 5. of February of the ≈øaid yeare: they could not come to agree of the ≈øaid Peace, for many great difficulties hapning among them: For which cau≈øe, the Lords Amba≈ø≈øadors of the mo≈øt Chri≈øtian Kings, and of great Britayne, of the Princes electors Palatine and Brandenburg, Marques of Ansbach, and Lantgraue of He≈ø≈øen, ≈øent thither on the behalfe of the ≈øaid Lords, Kings and Princes, to the aide, and furtherance of ≈øo good a worke: ≈øeeing that they were readie to depart and to break off al Treaty; did propo≈øe a Truce for many yeares, on certaine conditions contained in a writing, by them deliuered to both parties, with entreaty and exhortation to agree thereunto. Vpon the which writing, many other difficulties likewi≈øe hapning.

In the end, this ninth day of April, in the yeare 1609. there a≈ø≈øembled Seignior Ambro≈øio Spinola, Marques de Benafro, Knight of the order of the Golden Fleece, Coun≈øellor of E≈øtate, and of the Warres to his Catholike Maie≈øtie, Ma≈øter of the Camp, Generall of his Armies: and Seignior Iohn Richardot Knight, Lord of Barby, Coun≈øellor of E≈øtate, and chiefe Pre≈øident of their Highne≈ø≈øes priuie Coun≈øell: Iohn de Mancicidor, of the Coun≈øell of warre, and Secretary to his ≈øaid Catholike Maie≈øtie. The reuerend father frier Iohn Neyen, Commi≈øsioner generall of the order of Saint Francis in the Low-Countries: and Seignior Loys Verreyken Knight, Ma≈øter of the reque≈øts and chiefe Secretary to their Highne≈ø≈øes, &c. By vertue of the letters of procuration from the ≈øaid Lords Archdukes, to treat as well in their names, as in the name of the Lord King
Catholike; the tenor of which procuration is hereafter in≈øerted: with the like al≈øo of the ≈øaid Kings on the one part, and Seignior Loys Earle of Na≈øsaw, Catzenellebogen, Vyanden Dietz &c. Lord of Bil≈øteyn, Gouernour and Captaine gene-ral of Frize, the Citie of Groeningen and Ommelanden Drente, &c. Seignior Walrauen Lord of Bredero, Vianen, Vicounte of Vtrecht, L. of Ameyden, Cloetengen, &c. The L. Cornelius of Gendt, Lord of Loeuen and Meyner≈øwick, Vicount & Iudge of the Empire, and of the Citie of Nuninegen: Seig. Iehan of Oldenbarneuelt Knight, Lord of Cimpell, Rodenris, &c. Aduocate and keeper of the great Seale, Charters and Regi≈øters of Holland and We≈øt-Frizeland: Seignior Iaques of Malderee Knight, Lord of Heyes, &c. The chiefe, and repre≈øenting the Nobility of the E≈øtates and Coun≈øell of the countie of Zealand; the Lords Girard de Rene≈ø≈øe, Lord Vander Aa. of Streeffkirck Niew Lecker landt, &c. Iellius Hillena Doctor of the lawes, Coun≈øellor ordinary of the Coun≈øell of Frize: Iohn Sloeten Lord of Sallicq, Dro≈ø≈øart of the County of Vellenhoo, and Steward of the Seigneury of Claunder, & Abel Coenders of Helpen, Lord In Faien and Cantes, in the name of the ≈øaid Lordes E≈øtates, as al≈øo by vertue of their Letters of procurations and Commi≈øsion hereafter likewi≈øe in≈øerted on the other part; who together with the mediation and adui≈øe of Lord Iohn Charles Baron of Chagnie, and Monyeu Coun≈øellor of E≈øtate to the mo≈øt chri≈øtian King, and his Emba≈øsador extraordinary, with the ≈øaid lordes E≈øtates.

And the Lord Elias de la Place Knight, lord of Ru≈ø≈øy, Vicount of Marchault, Coun≈øellor al≈øo in the ≈øaid Coun≈øell of E≈øtate, Gentleman in ordinary of the ≈øaid Lord, the kings chamber, Baylife and Captaine of Vitry le Francois and his ordinarie Amba≈ø≈øador, with the ≈øaid lordes, the e≈øtates. Sir Richard Spencer knight, Gentleman in ordinarie, of the king of great
Britaynes priuie chamber, and his Amba≈øsador extraordinary, vnto the ≈øaid Lordes the E≈øtates, and Sir Raphe Winwood knight Amba≈ø≈øador ordinary, and Coun≈øellor to the ≈øaid king in his Coun≈øell of e≈øtate, in the vnited Prouinces, haue accorded and agreed, in the manner and forme following.

div.head: ARTICLES OF TRVCE. Made in the Citie of ANTVVERP, the 9. of April 1609. betweene the Commi≈øsioners of the mo≈øt Excellent Princes, Archdukes ALBERT and ISABELLA CLARA EVGENIA, and the E≈øtates Generall of the Vnited PROVINCES ‚Ä¢ f the LOVV-COVNTRYES.
div.p:
FIr≈øt, the ≈øaid Archdukes and Dutches ≈øignifie and declare, not onely in their owne Names, but al≈øo in the Name of the King of Spaine, that they are well plea≈øed and content to enter into Treatie with the E≈øtates Generall of the Vnited Prouinces in qualitie, and as holding, accounting and e≈øteeming them to be free Countryes, Prouinces and E≈øtates, whereunto they pretend not any Right or Title of Soueraigntie, and in the Names and qualities afore≈øaid, at this pre≈øent to make a
Truce with them, vpon ≈øuch Articles and Conditions as hereafter en≈øueth.

II. That is, that the ≈øaid Truce ≈øhall bee good Firme, Loyall and Inuiolable, and ≈øhall continue and indure for the ≈øpace of Twelue yeeres, and that during the ≈øaid time, there ≈øhall bee an ab≈øtinence and di≈øcontinuance, and cea≈øing from all Actes of Ho≈øtilitie in any manner and fa≈øhion what≈øoeuer, betweene the ≈øaid King of Spaine, the Archduke and Dutches and the States Generall, as well by Sea and in all other Waters and Riuers, as by Land in all Kingdoms, Countryes, Lands and Signiories, and betweene all their Subiects and Inhabitants, of what qualitie or condition ≈øo euer they bee, without exception of place or Per≈øons.

III. That either Side ≈øhall po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe, and effectually enioy all tho≈øe Countries, Townes, Places, Landes, and Signiories, which they at this pre≈øent hold, po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe and enioy, without any trouble, mole≈øtation, or contradiction what≈øoeuer, during the continuance of the ≈øaid Truce, wherein it is intended and to be vnder≈øtood, that the Boroughs, Villages, Hamlets, and plaine Countries thereunto depending, ≈øhall be comprehended.

IIII. That the Subiectes and Inhabitants of the ≈øaid Countries, belonging vnto the afore≈øaid King, Archdukes, and States, ≈øhall haue and v≈øe all maner of good corre≈øpondence, and amitie one with the other, during the time of the ≈øaid Truce, without calling to mind, or remembring any of the offences, hurts, and dammages, that they or any of them haue receiued, had, and endured in the forepa≈ø≈øed
Warres, and trouble≈øome times, and ≈øhall and may freely frequent, inhabite, and dwell in each others Countries, and there v≈øe and exerci≈øe their Trades, and trafficke of Merchandizes, with all ≈øecuritie, both by Sea, and in other Riuers and waters, and al≈øo by Land: which neuerthele≈ø≈øe the ≈øaid King of Spaine vnder≈øtandeth to bee re≈øtrayned and limitted vnto the Kingdomes, Countries, Lands, and Seignories, which he holdeth and po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øeth in Europe, and in other places & ≈øeas, where the ≈øubiects of the Kings and Princes that are his Friendes and Alies, haue the ≈øaid free trafficke: and touching the Places, Townes, Ports, and Hauens, which hee holdeth out of the Limits afore≈øaid, that the ≈øaid States and their ≈øubiects, ≈øhall nor may not v≈øe any trade or trafficke there, without the licence and expre≈ø≈øe permi≈ø≈øion of the ≈øaid King: notwith≈øtanding, they ≈øhall and may freely trade and trafficke (if they thinke it good) in the Countries of all other Princes, Potentates, and People, that ≈øhall or will permit, ≈øuffer, and graunt them leaue, and that without the ≈øaid Limits, without any let, trouble or impeachment (of the ≈øaid King, his Officers and Subiectes, that depend on him) for that cau≈øe giuen, vnto the ≈øaid Princes, Potentates, and People, which haue permitted, or hereafter ≈øhal permit, ≈øuffer and grant it vnto them: nor vnto them of any of them in generall or particular, with whom they haue heretofore trafficked, or hereafter ≈øhall trafficke.

V. And for that it is requi≈øite that a rea≈øonable long time ≈øhould bee granted and ≈øet downe, wherein to aduerti≈øe tho≈øe, that are out of the ≈øaid Limits with Ships and martiall Forces, to de≈øi≈øt and ab≈øtaine from all actes of ho≈øtility; It is agreed and concluded, that the Truce afore≈øaid
≈øhall not begin till this day twelue moneth: alwaies prouided, that if notice of the ≈øaid Truce may ≈øooner bee ≈øent vnto them, that from that time forth all Actes of ho≈øtilitie ≈øhall cea≈øe, but if after the ≈øpace of one yeere, any act of ho≈øtilitie ≈øhal there be v≈øed and committed, the dammages done and receiued thereby, ≈øhall bee re≈øtored againe without any remi≈ø≈øion.

VI. That the Subiects and Inhabitants of the Countries of the ≈øaid King, Archdukes, and States, trading and trafficking mutually in each others Countries, ≈øhall not be bound to pay greater cu≈øtomes, rights and impo≈øitions, then the naturall ≈øubiects of the ≈øaid Countries, and of their friends and allies, that ≈øhall in that point be lea≈øt charged and burthened.

VII. That the Subiects and Inhabitants of the States in the vnited Prouinces, ≈øhall haue the ≈øame ≈øecuritie and libertie in the Countries of the ≈øaid King and the Archdukes, that hath beene granted vnto the Subiects of the King of great Brittaine, by the la≈øt Treatie of Peace, and ≈øecret Articles made and concluded with the Con≈øtable of Ca≈øtile.

VIII. That the Marchants, Ma≈øters of ≈øhips, Pilots, Saylers, Ships, Merchandi≈øes, Money, and other goods belonging vnto them, ≈øhall not be ≈øei≈øed vpon nor arre≈øted, by vertue of any Mandament or Commi≈ø≈øion generall or particular, nor for any cau≈øe concerning the warres, or otherwi≈øe, neither yet vnder any pretence of v≈øing them or any of them for the con≈øeruation and defence of the Countries on either ≈øide. Neuerthele≈ø≈øe it is to be vnder≈øtood, that Sea≈øures and Are≈øts made by the ordinarie wayes of Law,
and Iu≈øtice, for Debts, Obligations and contracts depending thereon, whereby the ≈øaid Sea≈øures and Are≈øts haue beene made, ≈øhall not bee comprehended herein, but that touching them, they ≈øhall bee proceeded in according to the ordinarie cu≈øtomes of Law and rea≈øon.

IX. And touching Trade and Traficke in the Netherlands, and the Taxes and Impo≈øitions that ≈øhall be taken and Leuied vpon Wares and Merchandi≈øes, if hereafter it ≈øhall be found that they are exce≈ø≈øiue great and intollerable, and that thereby ≈øome hinderance may growe vnto the Subiects of the ≈øaid Countryes, vpon the fir≈øt motion and reque≈øt made by the one, or the other part, certaine Committies ≈øhall be appointed to order and moderate the ≈øame, by common con≈øent, if it may bee done. And yet neuerthele≈ø≈øe, without any breach of the Truce, although they cannot agree vpon the ≈øame.

X. If any ≈øentences or iudgements ≈øhall haue beene giuen vpon, or again≈øt any per≈øon on either ≈øide, (not excepted) either in ciuill or criminal cau≈øes, they ≈øhal not be executed vpon the per≈øons or goods of the parties condemned, during the time of the ≈øaid Truce.

XI. That no letters of Marte, and repri≈øall ≈øhall bee granted or giuen out, during the ≈øaid time, without good cau≈øe knowne, and in ≈øuch ca≈øes wherein it is permitted to be done, by the imperiall lawes and Con≈øtitutions, and according to the Orders e≈øtabli≈øhed and appointed by them.

XII. That it ≈øhall not be lawfull to arriue, enter nor ≈øtay in
any Port, Hauen, Place or Roade in the countrie on either ≈øide, with Shippes, or ≈øuch numbers of Souldiers as may breede any cau≈øe of ≈øu≈øpition, without the leaue and permi≈ø≈øion of him or them, to whom the ≈øaid Ports, Hauens, Places and Roades ≈øhal belong and appertaine, vnle≈ø≈øe they be forced to doe it by tempe≈øts, or of meere nece≈ø≈øity, to auoyde the danger of the Seas.

XIII. That they, who≈øe goods and lands haue bin ≈øea≈øed vpon and confi≈øcated by meanes of the warres, or their heires, hauing good cau≈øe, ≈øhall enioy their ≈øaid goods during the ≈øaid truce; and ≈øhall enter and take po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion thereof, by their owne priuate authority, and by vertue of this pre≈øent Treatie, without any recour≈øe vnto Law or Iu≈øtice: Notwith≈øtanding, any Incorporations, Confi≈øcations, Morgages, Gifts, Contracts, Articles of agreement and tran≈øportations, or any renunciations made in the ≈øaid tran≈øportations, thereby to exclude any part of the ≈øaid lands and goods, from them to whom they ought to appertaine; vpon charge and condition, neuerthele≈ø≈øe, that they neyther ≈øhall nor may di≈øpo≈øe thereof, nor yet rai≈øe nor dimini≈øh the rents of the ≈øame, during the time that they ≈øhall enioy and po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe them, without licence and permi≈ø≈øion fir≈øt had, and obtained from the ≈øaid Archdukes or the States.

XIIII. Which al≈øo ≈øhall take place for, and to the profite of the heire of the Prince of Orange decea≈øed: namely, touching the rights which they pretend to haue in the ≈øalt pondes, in the Countie of Bourgoigne, which ≈øhall be permitted and quietly left vnto them; together with the Woods belonging to the ≈øame. And touching the Proce≈ø≈øe
concerning Cha≈øtelbelin, begun in the life time of the ≈øaid Prince of Orenge decea≈øed, in the Court of Madrynes, again≈øt the King of Spaines Attorney generall; the ≈øayde Archdukes faithfully promi≈øe, to cau≈øe Iu≈øtice to bee done therein, within the ≈øpace of one yeare next en≈øuing, after the pur≈øuite by them to be made, without any delay, and with all ≈øincerity and right.

XV. If the Fi≈øcall on either ≈øide, ≈øhall haue ≈øolde any goods or lands confi≈øcated; they, to whom they ought to appertaine, by vertue of this pre≈øent Treatie, ≈øhall be bound to content them≈øelues with the intere≈øt of the price thereof, according to the la≈øt ≈øea≈øure, which ≈øhal be paide vnto them yearely during the Truce, by them that holde and po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe the ≈øame, or el≈øe it ≈øhal be lawful for them to adre≈ø≈øe them≈øelues vnto the Heritage it ≈øelfe that hath bin ≈øold.

XVI. But if the ≈øaid Sales haue beene made by order of Law and Iu≈øtice, for, and in con≈øideration of the Truce, and lawfull debts of tho≈øe, to whom the ≈øaid lands and goods did appertaine before the confi≈øcation made, it ≈øhall be lawful for them, or their heires vpon occa≈øion offered, to redeeme them, paying the ≈øumme for the which they were ≈øolde, within one yeares time from the day of this pre≈øent Treatie: after the which time, they ≈øhall not be permitted to do it; and the ≈øaid redemption hauing bin made by them, they may di≈øpo≈øe thereof as they ≈øhall thinke good, without ≈øeeking after any other licence or permi≈ø≈øion.

XVII. Neuerthele≈ø≈øe, it is not vnder≈øtood that this redemption ≈øhall tend vnto, or concerne ≈øuch hou≈øes as are ≈øituated in townes, and ≈øold for that cau≈øe, in regard of the great di≈øcommodities
& notable damages that the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øors therof ≈øhall thereby reape, by meanes of the alterations and reparations that they may haue made and done, in, and vnto the ≈øaid hou≈øes, whereof the liquidation would be ouer long and difficulte.

XVIII. Touching the reparations and alterations, made in, and vpon other lands and goods ≈øold, which are permitted to be reduced, if there be any ≈øuch pretence made and called in que≈øtion; the ordinary Iudges ≈øhall do each partie right and equity, according to the indifferency of the cau≈øe, the Inheritances remaining to the owners that ≈øue for the ≈øame; for the ≈øumme wherunto the reparations or alterations ≈øhal be pri≈øed, without any right of holding or keeping of po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion (to be permitted vnto tho≈øe that ≈øhall haue bought them) vntill they ≈øhall be paide and fully ≈øatisfied therein.

XIX. If any fortifications or publike works haue bin made on eyther part with permi≈ø≈øion and authority of the ≈øuperiors, in ≈øuch places where re≈øtitution ought to be made by this pre≈øent Treatie; the proprietaries therof ≈øhal content them≈øelues with the e≈øtimation and valuation that ≈øhall be made thereof, by the ordinary Iudges, both of the ≈øaid places, and al≈øo of the iuri≈ødiction that they had therein, vntill the parties them≈øelues can otherwi≈øe agree thereon.

XX. Touching the lands and goods of Churches, Colledges, and other ≈øpirituall places, within the vnited Prouinces, that were members depending vpon, and belonging vnto the Churches, Benefices and Colledges, that are vnder the obedience of the Archduke, which haue not bin ≈øolde before
the fir≈øt of Ianuary 1607. ≈øhall be re≈øtored vnto them againe; and they ≈øhall enter into, and po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe the ≈øame by their own priuat authority, without any officer of Iu≈øtice, and ≈øhall enioy the ≈øame during the ≈øaid Truce, & yet without di≈øpo≈øing thereof as afore≈øaid; but ≈øuch lands and goods as haue beene ≈øolde before the ≈øaid time, or giuen in payment by the Sates of any of the Prouinces; the rent of the value thereof, ≈øhall be paid them euery yeare, according to the la≈øt ≈øea≈øure, by the Prouince that ≈øhall haue made the ≈øaid ≈øale, and giuen or a≈ø≈øigned the ≈øaid goods in payment as afore≈øaid, ≈øo that they may be a≈ø≈øured thereof. The like ≈øhall be done and ob≈øerued on the part and behalfe of the ≈øaid Archdukes.

XXI. Tho≈øe to whom the goods and lands confi≈øcated ought to be re≈øtored, ≈øhall not be bound to pay the arerages of rents, charges and dueties, ≈øpecially impo≈øed and re≈øerued vpon the ≈øaid lands and goods, for the time that they enioyed not the ≈øame; and if they be ≈øued, mole≈øted or troubled for the ≈øame, on either part, they ≈øhal be freely acquited and ab≈øolued thereof.

XXII. No pretence of any payment ≈øhall be made, touching hedging or ditching of the Lands ≈øolde, or to bee redeemed, but onely for ≈øuch conditions or cu≈øtoms, as were anciently accu≈øtomed to be v≈øed and ob≈øerued, whereunto the Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øors are bound, by the Articles of agreement made thereupon, with the intere≈øts of the money payable at the entrie into po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, if any haue beene giuen, by rea≈øon of the la≈øt ≈øei≈øure, as afore≈øaid.

XXIII. Iudgements giuen touching lands and goods confi≈øcated,
again≈øt ≈øuch parties as haue obeyed the Iudges, and haue bin lawfully excepted, ≈øhall be held for good and lawfull, wherein ≈øuch as are condemned, ≈øhall not be permitted or allowed any appeale, but only by ordinary meanes.

XXIIII. The ≈øaid Archdukes, and the States, either of them for their parts, ≈øhall appoint Officers and Magi≈øtrates to admini≈øter law and iu≈øtice in the Townes, and ≈øtrong Holds, which by this pre≈øent Treatie, are to bee yeelded vp, vnto ≈øuch as owe them, to enioy them according to the Truce.
XXV. Such moueable goodes and fruits as are and haue beene confi≈øcated before the conclu≈øion of this pre≈øent Treatie, ≈øhall not be ≈øubiect vnto re≈øtitution.

XXVI. Such actions or ≈øuites, as haue bin remitted by the ≈øaid Archdukes or the States, for the profite of particular debtors, before the fir≈øt of Ianuarie 1607. ≈øhall bee di≈øanulled on both ≈øides.

XXVII. The time that hath pa≈øt ≈øince the beginning of the warres, from the yeere of our Lord 1567. vntill this pre≈øent yeere, ≈øhall not bee reckoned to induce any pre≈øcription, betweene ≈øuch per≈øons as were of diuers parties.

XXVIII. Tho≈øe that withdrew them≈øelues into neuter Countries, during the warres, ≈øhall al≈øo enioy the benefite of this Truce, and may dwell and inhabite where they ≈øhall thinke good, and returne againe vnto their ancient habitations, there to dwell and continue in all ≈øecuritie, ob≈øeruing the lawes of the Countrie, and no occa≈øion of dwelling in any place, where they ≈øhall thinke good, ≈øhall be any cau≈øe,
why their goods ≈øhall or may be confi≈øcated, or ≈øea≈øed vpon, nor they ≈øhall not in that ca≈øe bee depriued of the enioying thereof.
XXIX. No newe Forts ≈øhall bee made during the ≈øaid Truce, within the Low Countries, neither on the one ≈øide nor the other.

XXX. The Lords of the Hou≈øe of Na≈ø≈øaw, ≈øhall not be pur≈øued, or yet mole≈øted, during the ≈øaid Truce, neither in their per≈øons, goods nor lands, for any debts made by the ≈øaid Prince of Orange decea≈øed, from the yeere of our Lord, 1567. vntill the day of his death, nor yet of the arrerages hapned and fallen out, during the ≈øea≈øing and withholding of the lands and goods that were chargeable for the ≈øame.

XXXI. If there be any preuentions of the Truce made by any particular per≈øons, without the commandement or permi≈ø≈øion of the ≈øaid King, Archdukes, or States, the dammages ≈øhall be recouered in the ≈øame place, where the ≈øaid Preuentions haue bin made, if the parties bee found therein, or el≈øe in the place where they ≈øhall dwell, without any pur≈øuite el≈øewhere to be made again≈øt them, either in their bodies or goods, in any ≈øort what≈øoeuer: neither ≈øhall it be lawful for them to enter into armes, or to breake the Truce for that occa≈øion, but they ≈øhall be permitted (if it be manife≈øtly proued that iu≈øtice ≈øhall in that ca≈øe be denyed) to remedie them≈øelues, as the maner is, by letters of marte or repri≈øals.

XXXII. All di≈ø-inheritings and di≈øpo≈øitions made of landes in
hatred and di≈øpight of the whore, are hereby declared void, and vtterly fru≈øtrated.

XXXIII. The Subiects and Inhabitants of the Countries of the ≈øaid Archdukes, and the States, of what ≈øtate and condition ≈øoeuer they bee, are hereby declared capable to bee heires and ≈øucce≈ø≈øors one vnto the other, both by te≈øtament, and al≈øo ab inte≈øtato, according to the cu≈øtomes of the places: and if any Succe≈ø≈øions did heretofore fall and e≈øcheat vnto any of them, they ≈øhall be maintayned and con≈øerued.
XXXIIII. All Pri≈øoners of the warres, ≈øhall be deliuered on both Sides, without paying any ran≈øomes.

XXXV. And to the end that this pre≈øent Treatie ≈øhall the better be ob≈øerued and kept, The ≈øaid King of Spaine, the Archdukes, and the States doe particularly promi≈øe, to vphold and maintaine the ≈øame, and each of them to v≈øe all the meanes they can to make all the pa≈ø≈øages Free, and to cau≈øe the Seas and Riuers within the Land to be kept free and Nauigable, again≈øt the incur≈øions of mutinous Per≈øons, Pirates, Cur≈øaries and Theeues, and that if they can apprehend and take them, to cau≈øe them to bee rigorou≈øly puni≈øhed according to their de≈øerts.

XXXVI. They doe al≈øo promi≈øe, to doe nothing contrarie, or to the preiudice of this pre≈øent Treatie, nor to ≈øuffer the ≈øame to bee done directly or indirectly in my wife what≈øoeuer, and that if any ≈øuch thing be done, to cau≈øe it to bee amended and recompenced; without any difficultie or delay. And for the ob≈øeruation of all the former Articles, the
≈øaid King of Spaine and the Archdukes and their Succe≈ø≈øors, bind them≈øelues particularly, and for the more and better a≈ø≈øurance of their ≈øaid Obligations and promi≈øes, they renownce all Lawes, Cu≈øtomes and things what≈øoeuer contrarie to the ≈øame.

XXXVII. That this pre≈øent Treatie ≈øhall be ratified, and approoued by the ≈øaid Kings, the Archdukes and the States, and the Letters of ratification made by the ≈øaid Archdukes and the States, to bee deliuered by the one vnto the other, in good and due forme, within foure dayes next en≈øuing. And touching the ratification to bee made by then ≈øaid King of Spaine, The ≈øaid Archdukes haue promi≈øed, and are bound, to giue and deliuer it vnto the ≈øaid States, within three Moneths in good and due forme, to the end that the ≈øaid States, and their Subiects and Inhabitants, may effectually enioy the fruites of this pre≈øent Treatie with all ≈øecuritie.

XXXVIII. That the ≈øaid Treatie ≈øhall bee publi≈øhed in all places, where it is v≈øually to bee Proclaimed, pre≈øently after the ratification made by the ≈øaid Archdukes and the States, and that pre≈øently and from henceforth all Acts of Ho≈øtilitie ≈øhall cea≈øe.
